did.abstract: This group consists of several editions of Charles Willson Peale's autobiography: a fragment of a preliminary draft begun by C. W. Peale in 1790, a more extensive version begun in 1826, a transcribed copy of the 1826 manuscript by great-grandson Horace Wells Sellers (1896?), and a typed copy of this transcribed version with notes and an index (dated 1904) also by Horace Wells Sellers.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Charles Coleman Sellers and accessioned, 1945.

altformavail.head: Existence and Location of Copies note
altformavail.p: This collection is also available on microfilm (Film 240). The papers of C. W. Peale and his family have been reproduced almost in their entirety in microfiche form (Lillian B. Miller, ed. "Collected papers of Charles Willson Peale and his family." Kraus Microfilm, 1980).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: The main body of the Peale Collection is described in brief in American Philosophical Society Library "Year Book" 1945:74-77.

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Charles Willson Peale was an artist and naturalist.

odd.head: Early American History Not
odd.p: The autobiographies of Charles Wilson Peale (there are really two in this collection) are remarkable documents. The first, written in 1790, sketches out Peale’s life up to this point and is in a small, pocket sized bound volume. Peale recounts his exploits in the Revolutionary War and after it. The final copy, written in the early nineteenth century(likely 1826), consists of several hundred pages of detailed reminiscences of his life, an autobiography written for publication as a complement to his painted Artist in His Museum.
